General blooming and Foliage

Miombo trees are deciduous, losing most of their leaves during the dry season(winter).The most visually striking period is the late dry season flush in early spring, usually around August and September, just before the onset of the rain. During this time the woodlands are covered by vibrant nee foliage of red, orange and yellow hues.

Julbenardia globiflora flowering season to February and March, Brachystegia spiciformis August to September and Pterocarpus tinctorius March to May.

These variations mean that while there is a peak period for a new foliage, the overall blooming of different species can spam much of the year

item.title: New Feeds
item.dc:creator: Stephano Semba
item.description:
The Miombo woodlands are vital ecosystems for both communities and wildlife. The Mlele Forest Reserve, located in Mlele District, is a prime example, providing essential resources and serving as a crucial year-round water catchment via the Kapapa River.

  • The Mlele Hill Forest Reserve is ecologically vital, crucially maintaining water quality. The perennial flow of the Kapapa River is a direct indicator of the forest’s health and its support for wildlife.

item.title: My New post
item.dc:creator: Stephano Semba
item.description:
Stephano Semba is integrating data science with his conservation background to solve emerging environmental challenges. This skillset is an asset for both his career growth and his institute’s impact. Data science empowers and advances national conservation efforts

  • Emerging conservation challenges—driven by poverty, agricultural expansion, and demand for timber—are causing significant forest degradation and loss. Data science provides a powerful solution by using computation and analysis to accurately measure forest cover and deliver critical insights to policymakers and institutions.
